title: How to Grow Roses Organically

steps.headline: Plant the roses in a sunny garden with enough space for them to grow.
steps.description: The size of the root system and bush will depend on the species of rose that you’re growing. A quick search of the rose type online will tell you how large the bush might get. They can range in size from 1 foot (0.30 m) mini bushes to very large climbers that can easily cover a building. Roses can grow in many different climates as long as they receive ample sunlight throughout the day. Roses require full sun, or 6 hours of direct sunlight. Amend the soil with compost or sand before planting rose bushes so the soil is well-drained.

steps.headline: Give your roses plenty of water when you first plant them.
steps.description: During the first 1-2 years, water them often enough to keep the soil moist at all times. After that, water the plant with equal amounts of water 2-3 times per week. The soil should be dry at a depth of 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) before additional water is given.

steps.headline: Create a watering regimen for your roses once they are established.
steps.description: Roses are thirsty plants that require regular irrigation from spring through fall and even throughout the winter in hot climates. The amount of water required by a rose bush depends on its size and the temperature. When daytime temperatures stay below 80 degrees Fahrenheit, give mini roses 2 gallons (7.6 L) of water each week. Medium-sized shrub roses need about 3 to 4 gallons (11 to 15 L) each week. Give large hybrid teas 6 gallons (23 L) each week. When daytime temperatures rise up to over 80 or 90 degrees Fahrenheit, double the number of gallons given to the rose each time.

steps.headline: Water the roses in the morning.
steps.description: Before temperatures rise in the afternoon, water the plants thoroughly until the ground is moist. The roses will use the water throughout the day as it drains through the soil, and the water will have enough time to percolate without evaporating in the sun. If you live in a dry area, spread 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) of shredded bark mulch around the roses to keep the soil moist and reduce the need for frequent irrigation.

steps.headline: Use an organic rose-friendly fertilizer.
steps.description: Organic fertilizers commonly contain kelp meal, bone meal, chicken manure or alfalfa meal along with other ingredients. Select an organic fertilizer with a Nitrogen-Phosphorus-Potassium (NPK) ratio of 5-7-2, 4-6-2 or an all-purpose 10-10-10 fertilizer. Nitrogen promotes foliage and Phosphorus promotes flowers. Potassium promotes overall health. Spray compost tea on the leaves and water the soil with it to encourage beneficial bacteria growth. This helps reduce fungus and pest problems.

steps.headline: Apply fertilizer in the springtime to ensure healthy plants.
steps.description: Feed the roses for the first time in the spring when new foliage first appears. A springtime feeding will be adequate for most small and medium bushes, but larger bushes may need an additional round of fertilizer at the end of the spring bloom period. Do not give roses fertilizer after the middle of August as it will encourage new growth that may not mature in time for winter weather.

steps.headline: Give your rose the correct amount of fertilizer for its species.
steps.description: The amount of fertilizer to give each rose varies, depending on the size of the rose and the fertilizer formulation. In general, apply about 0.5 to 1 cup (120 to 240 mL) per plant in an 18 in (46 cm) circle around the base of the plant. Be sure to follow the manufacturer’s application instructions carefully. Make sure to water the soil before applying any fertilizer. The fertilizer can burn a rose’s roots if the roots are dry. Work dry fertilizer into the top 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of soil before watering the rose.

steps.headline: Pinch away faded blooms.
steps.description: When the roses are blooming, remove the faded blossoms to encourage more flowers to grow. This process is called “deadheading.” Make sure to dispose of the dead heads in the compost pile, rather than leaving them on the ground. Regularly remove broken branches or stems to keep them from interfering with the growth of the plant.

steps.headline: Prune roses in the springtime.
steps.description: In the early spring, use sharp bypass pruners to cut back dead stems. Only cut the stems that don’t have any new buds on them to encourage growth in the following year. Dull and anvil-type pruners will crush the rose stem, causing serious damage to the bush.

steps.headline: Cut the stems at a 45-degree angle just beyond an outward-facing growth bud.
steps.description: Growth buds on rose stems are usually located where a leaf with five leaflets is growing. Make sure it’s an outward-facing bud so it encourages outward growth. The new stem will grow from the growth bud just below the pruning cut. After you prune your plant, wipe down your shears to prevent rust and store them in a cool, dry area.

steps.headline: Prune according to the species’ needs, which can vary.
steps.description: The amount of the rose that should be pruned off depends on the type of rose you’re growing. For example, shrub roses and mini roses usually only need light pruning to shape them after they have been planted for two years. Cut back all of the stems on large roses, like hybrid teas, by about two-thirds every year. Be sure to remove any dead branches that have fallen or are rubbing against other, healthy branches throughout the year.

steps.headline: Remove the foliage in the winter if you live in a hot climate.
steps.description: In hot climates where roses are not exposed to freezing temperatures, prune off all of the leaves in January so the rose can start fresh each spring. Seal stems that are thicker than a pencil with white household glue to keep insects out. This ensures that the stems will continue growing thicker and that there will be healthy, new foliage for the upcoming growing season.

steps.headline: Watch for aphids, scales, mealy bugs, Japanese beetles, and spider mites.
steps.description: Eliminate insect infestations by spraying roses with the hose every two or three days to knock the pests off the plant. Use a spray nozzle set for a strong stream to dislodge the pests with the water.If you’re unsure if you have an infestation, check the undersides of leaves for small insects that excrete a clear, sticky liquid. Scale insects look like raised lumps on the undersides of leaves. Mealy bugs look like fuzzy white patches on leaves and stems. Japanese beetles are bright green, and they eat the buds and flowers of roses. These can be picked off by hand. Check for small web-like structures on your plant, since this could mean there are spider mites.

steps.headline: Use a mixture of dish soap, horticultural oil, and water to kill pests.
steps.description: Mix 2 drops of liquid dish soap and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of oil per 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water. Spray the solution on the tops and bottoms of the leaves as well as on the stems until the mixture drips from the rose. Spray in the morning or evening when temperatures are cooler and rinse the solution off after two to three hours.

steps.headline: Add baking soda to the mixture to fight mildew and black spot.
steps.description: Spray the infected leaves once per week with 1 tbsp (18 g) of baking soda mixed with 2 drops of dish soap and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of horticultural oil per 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water. To prevent infection in humid weather, spray the entire bush once per week even if it has not been infected by mildew or black spot to prevent outbreaks.

steps.headline: Encourage good insects to live in your garden.
steps.description: Add nectar-rich plants such as dill, fennel, and so on to attract insects that are healthy for your roses. With biodiversity and integrated pest management, you can potentially reduce the amount of harmful bugs that decide to snack upon your beloved rose bushes. Ladybugs are an example of a beneficial insect that can control pests on rose bushes. They will eat any aphids that happen to wander onto your bushes. Be sure to contact your local pest control office to make sure you aren’t introducing a dangerous insect that could hurt the environment.

steps.headline: Trim away diseased parts of the plant.
steps.description: If your rose bushes are suffering from black spot, remove all the damaged or ailing leaves and tidy up around the plant to prevent the spread of infection. Remove the mulch and fallen leaves around your plant, and replace it with fresh mulch. Heavily infected specimens may also require heavy pruning to get rid of diseased parts. After trimming a diseased bush, be sure to disinfect your garden tools to prevent spreading black spot. Dispose of the diseased trimmings in the garbage instead of a compost pile to ensure your other plants are safe.
